elements.content: 3D printed micrometer-scale polymer mounts for single crystal analysis have been prepared by photopolymerization using digital light projection stereolithography (DLP-SLA), with a commercially available digital light projection stereolithography printer (US$4000) and 3DM-ABS resin (US$150 per liter). The polymer mounts were prepared in batches of 49 in 1 h 15 min, which allowed for rapid prototyping and testing of new crystal mounting designs, with a resin cost of 0.2¢ US per mount. The suitability of the 3D printed mounts for single crystal crystallography has been demonstrated through their use in Cu Kα X-ray diffraction experiments of Rochelle salt (sodium potassium tartrate), the protein lysozyme, and has been employed for routine crystallographic analysis of organic and inorganic materials.
elements.clean_text: 3D printed micrometer-scale polymer mounts for single crystal analysis have been prepared by photopolymerization using digital light projection stereolithography (DLP-SLA), with a commercially available digital light projection stereolithography printer (US$4000) and 3DM-ABS resin (US$150 per liter). The polymer mounts were prepared in batches of 49 in 1 h 15 min, which allowed for rapid prototyping and testing of new crystal mounting designs, with a resin cost of 0.2¢ US per mount. The suitability of the 3D printed mounts for single crystal crystallography has been demonstrated through their use in Cu Kα X-ray diffraction experiments of Rochelle salt (sodium potassium tartrate), the protein lysozyme, and has been employed for routine crystallographic analysis of organic and inorganic materials.

elements.content: Additive manufacturing technology, more commonly referred to as 3D printing, is the process in which a digital CAD model can be directly fabricated into a physical object. There are a number of available techniques including fused deposition molding (FDM), stereolithography (SLA), inkjet/polyjet (i3DP), two photon lithography, selective laser sintering, and layered hydrospinning. A detailed review of these different methods has been recently published. Additive manufacturing is gaining broad attention in the bespoke preparation of laboratory equipment, with rapid prototyping and custom manufacturing providing great enhancements over the traditional means of R&D and production. Notable examples of custom 3D printed laboratory equipment include microfluidic devices from poly­(dimethylsiloxane), reactionware for hydrothermal reactions, gradient generators for nitrate detection in water, integrated valves, and modular microfluidic circuits.
elements.clean_text: Additive manufacturing technology, more commonly referred to as 3D printing, is the process in which a digital CAD model can be directly fabricated into a physical object. There are a number of available techniques including fused deposition molding (FDM), stereolithography (SLA), inkjet/polyjet (i3DP), two photon lithography, selective laser sintering, and layered hydrospinning. A detailed review of these different methods has been recently published. Additive manufacturing is gaining broad attention in the bespoke preparation of laboratory equipment, with rapid prototyping and custom manufacturing providing great enhancements over the traditional means of R&D and production. Notable examples of custom 3D printed laboratory equipment include microfluidic devices from poly(dimethylsiloxane), reactionware for hydrothermal reactions, gradient generators for nitrate detection in water, integrated valves, and modular microfluidic circuits.

elements.content: The synergies of 3D printing technologies with the crystallographic study of three-dimensional molecules has been noted for research applications as well as for chemical and crystallographic education. Open access repositories of 3D structure files, such as the NIH 3D Print Exchange, have broadened the appreciation and accessibility of 3D molecular structures to the scientific community and the general public. The applications of 3D printing technologies to crystallography have recently expanded from molecular model creation to the production of custom device components, specifically molds for pinhole apertures for X- and γ-ray imaging, and the 3D printing of a boron carbide (B4C)/ABS composite aperture for absorption control in small angle neutron scattering (SANS) experiments. 3D printed electrochemical devices for X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) with synchrotron radiation have also been prepared.
elements.clean_text: The synergies of 3D printing technologies with the crystallographic study of three-dimensional molecules has been noted for research applications as well as for chemical and crystallographic education. Open access repositories of 3D structure files, such as the NIH 3D Print Exchange, have broadened the appreciation and accessibility of 3D molecular structures to the scientific community and the general public. The applications of 3D printing technologies to crystallography have recently expanded from molecular model creation to the production of custom device components, specifically molds for pinhole apertures for X- and γ-ray imaging, and the 3D printing of a boron carbide (B4C)/ABS composite aperture for absorption control in small angle neutron scattering (SANS) experiments. 3D printed electrochemical devices for X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) with synchrotron radiation have also been prepared.

elements.content: Historically, room temperature measurements of inert crystals were often made by gluing single crystals to glass capillaries or even human hair. The advent and widespread usage of cryoconditions for crystal structure data collection has given rise to a number of techniques using viscous mounting oils that solidify below ambient temperatures. Commonly used loop materials for cryostream conditions, including cryoprotected protein crystals, include monofilament nylon loops. More advanced techniques have been developed to simplify crystal retrieval and data collection, with shaped polyimide micromounts, adhesive crystal catchers, automated microshovels, and magnetic assisted crystal harvesting among the most recent innovations. Dual fiber techniques have also been applied to allow for the manipulation of low symmetry space group crystals in situ on synchrotron beamlines, where restrictions on the rotational axes of the crystal impacts on the possible completeness and redundancy of the collected data. The use of these techniques, and increasing automation, are particularly important for the discipline of protein crystallography, where rapid throughput screening of fragment libraries is an essential requirement for the success of structure-based hit-to-lead drug discovery.
elements.clean_text: Historically, room temperature measurements of inert crystals were often made by gluing single crystals to glass capillaries or even human hair. The advent and widespread usage of cryoconditions for crystal structure data collection has given rise to a number of techniques using viscous mounting oils that solidify below ambient temperatures. Commonly used loop materials for cryostream conditions, including cryoprotected protein crystals, include monofilament nylon loops. More advanced techniques have been developed to simplify crystal retrieval and data collection, with shaped polyimide micromounts, adhesive crystal catchers, automated microshovels, and magnetic assisted crystal harvesting among the most recent innovations. Dual fiber techniques have also been applied to allow for the manipulation of low symmetry space group crystals in situ on synchrotron beamlines, where restrictions on the rotational axes of the crystal impacts on the possible completeness and redundancy of the collected data. The use of these techniques, and increasing automation, are particularly important for the discipline of protein crystallography, where rapid throughput screening of fragment libraries is an essential requirement for the success of structure-based hit-to-lead drug discovery.

elements.content: While the first FDM 3D printer was developed in 1986, it was not until the early 2000s that this technique was used for microfabrication, specifically to template microfluidic devices with poly­(dimethylsiloxane). The resolution of FDM typically limits microfabricated features to 500–1000 μm due to physical restrictions of the technique. Conversely, SLA fabrication offers higher resolution (typically 35–100 μm), however many of the SLA machines were high cost both to purchase, and run. The advent of lower cost laser light sources (specifically 405 nm), has allowed for desktop SLA machines such as the Form1 to become an affordable solution for small scale rapid-prototyping with SLA. In addition, DLP-SLA using high-resolution projectors have pushed the minimum feature size of microfabrication into the tens of microns (150 × 162 μm, XY) when fabricating negative features such as enclosed microfluidic channels. The minimum feature size of DLP-SLA fabricated structures are limited by the pixel size of the projector. Thus, when fabricating microstructures, the design must consider the XY pixel resolution as well as consideration to the photopolymer being used with regard to exposure time. In order to microfabricate a loop suitable for use in single crystal X-ray crystallography analysis, it is essential to create microvoids (on the order of 10–300 μm) contained within a thin loop of material. This thin loop is used to manipulate and mount the crystal, and potentially protect the crystal in a small reservoir of buffer. The minimal profile of the loop is desired to give low scattering of the incident radiation.
elements.clean_text: While the first FDM 3D printer was developed in 1986, it was not until the early 2000s that this technique was used for microfabrication, specifically to template microfluidic devices with poly(dimethylsiloxane). The resolution of FDM typically limits microfabricated features to 500-1000 μm due to physical restrictions of the technique. Conversely, SLA fabrication offers higher resolution (typically 35-100 μm), however many of the SLA machines were high cost both to purchase, and run. The advent of lower cost laser light sources (specifically 405 nm), has allowed for desktop SLA machines such as the Form1 to become an affordable solution for small scale rapid-prototyping with SLA. In addition, DLP-SLA using high-resolution projectors have pushed the minimum feature size of microfabrication into the tens of microns (150 × 162 μm, XY) when fabricating negative features such as enclosed microfluidic channels. The minimum feature size of DLP-SLA fabricated structures are limited by the pixel size of the projector. Thus, when fabricating microstructures, the design must consider the XY pixel resolution as well as consideration to the photopolymer being used with regard to exposure time. In order to microfabricate a loop suitable for use in single crystal X-ray crystallography analysis, it is essential to create microvoids (on the order of 10-300 μm) contained within a thin loop of material. This thin loop is used to manipulate and mount the crystal, and potentially protect the crystal in a small reservoir of buffer. The minimal profile of the loop is desired to give low scattering of the incident radiation.

elements.content: In an effort to push the boundaries of fine resolution 3D printing for laboratory applications and to introduce additive manufacture to another aspect of crystallography, we have manufactured and tested a number of polymer single crystal mounting loops and pins prepared on the micrometer scale.
elements.clean_text: In an effort to push the boundaries of fine resolution 3D printing for laboratory applications and to introduce additive manufacture to another aspect of crystallography, we have manufactured and tested a number of polymer single crystal mounting loops and pins prepared on the micrometer scale.

elements.content: 3DM-ABS resin photopolymer print material was purchased from Kudo 3D (California, U.S.A.). Deionized water was provided by a Merck Millipore purification system (MA, U.S.A.). The X-ray loops were designed using SolidWorks 2014–2015 (Dassault Systèmes SE, France) and were printed using a Titan 1 DLP-SLA 3D printer (Kudo 3D, California, U.S.A.). Slicing of .stl models was completed with Creation Workshop (DataTree3D, Dallas, Texas, U.S.A.). Contact angle images were taken using a Canon 60D DSLR (Canon Inc., Tokyo, Japan) with a 70 mm F2.8 EX DG Macro lens (Sigma Corp, Kawasaki, Japan). Droplets of deionized water (6 μL) were dispensed with an eVol XR digital analytical syringe (Trajan Scientific and Medical, Melbourne, Australia). For characterization of the microloops and measurement of contact angles, ImageJ (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland, U.S.A.) was used with Dropsnake.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

3DM-ABS resin photopolymer print material was purchased from Kudo 3D (California, U.S.A.). Deionized water was provided by a Merck Millipore purification system (MA, U.S.A.). The X-ray loops were designed using SolidWorks 2014-2015 (Dassault Systèmes SE, France) and were printed using a Titan 1 DLP-SLA 3D printer (Kudo 3D, California, U.S.A.). Slicing of .stl models was completed with Creation Workshop (DataTree3D, Dallas, Texas, U.S.A.). Contact angle images were taken using a Canon 60D DSLR (Canon Inc., Tokyo, Japan) with a 70 mm F2.8 EX DG Macro lens (Sigma Corp, Kawasaki, Japan). Droplets of deionized water (6 μL) were dispensed with an eVol XR digital analytical syringe (Trajan Scientific and Medical, Melbourne, Australia). For characterization of the microloops and measurement of contact angles, ImageJ (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland, U.S.A.) was used with Dropsnake.

elements.content: The crystal mounts were designed to be 74 × 74 × 600 μm pillars (X,Y,Z) with a 50 μm thick top, completing the loop as shown in a. The Titan 1 at maximum resolution has a pixel size of 37 μm, while the resin had a minimum layer thickness of 50 μm which determined the building blocks of the design to be 37 × 37 × 50 μm. In order to maximize fabrication yield, arrays of 7 × 7 pins (total 49) were fabricated on a single base of 20 × 20 × 0.5 mm; the design of the loops support pin was such that it could be placed into a metal holder for connection to a magnetic goniometer base. The pins were 14 mm long and designed to be easily snapped off from the base. The loops on the top of the pins were designed to be 6 pixels wide (222 μm) and 12 layers (600 μm) in length, as shown in b. The supporting structure consisted of 2 pixel (74 μm) wide pillars, with a one layer 10 pixel wide (370 μm) top. The STL file to reproduce the loops, and full CAD drawing (Figure S1) is available online as Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Design

The crystal mounts were designed to be 74 × 74 × 600 μm pillars (X,Y,Z) with a 50 μm thick top, completing the loop as shown in a. The Titan 1 at maximum resolution has a pixel size of 37 μm, while the resin had a minimum layer thickness of 50 μm which determined the building blocks of the design to be 37 × 37 × 50 μm. In order to maximize fabrication yield, arrays of 7 × 7 pins (total 49) were fabricated on a single base of 20 × 20 × 0.5 mm; the design of the loops support pin was such that it could be placed into a metal holder for connection to a magnetic goniometer base. The pins were 14 mm long and designed to be easily snapped off from the base. The loops on the top of the pins were designed to be 6 pixels wide (222 μm) and 12 layers (600 μm) in length, as shown in b. The supporting structure consisted of 2 pixel (74 μm) wide pillars, with a one layer 10 pixel wide (370 μm) top. The STL file to reproduce the loops, and full CAD drawing (Figure S1) is available online as Supporting Information.

elements.content: CAD illustrations of the X-ray loop design. (a) 3D CAD render of X-ray loop array showing arrangement of pins. (b) CAD drawing showing a close up of the loop design, all major dimensions are shown on the drawing in mm.
elements.clean_text: 1  CAD illustrations of the X-ray loop design. (a) 3D CAD render of X-ray loop array showing arrangement of pins. (b) CAD drawing showing a close up of the loop design, all major dimensions are shown on the drawing in mm.

elements.content: The Titan 1 was used with a photopolymer (3DM ABS) sensitive to the projector wavelength of 400 nm, which was poured into the printing bath. While the Titan 1 uses a stepper motor capable of 5 μm steps, Z-resolution was limited by the resin. The 3DM ABS material has a recommended fabrication range of 50–100 μm due to the photoinitiator/photoblocker selection. Hence, the Z resolution was determined by slicing the model at 50 μm into 331 layers in Creation Workshop. Fabrication of the base layer was for 30 s to allow for secure adhesion to the build platform, layer 2 was half of this at 15 s in order to allow for increased bonding of the rest of the build to the base. Subsequent layers of the design (layers 3–305) were exposed for 2 s, forming the crystal mount “pins”. A tapered point was fabricated (layers 306–318) using a lower exposure of 1.5 s in order to prevent overexposure; typically overexposure would result in larger structures than the intended design. Pillars (layers 319–330) forming the loops were exposed for 3 s and 2 s for the top. Total fabrication time was 1 h and 15 min to fabricate 49 loops. All X-ray loops were rinsed in isopropyl alcohol following fabrication to remove any residual, nonpolymerized resin and left to dry at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Fabrication

The Titan 1 was used with a photopolymer (3DM ABS) sensitive to the projector wavelength of 400 nm, which was poured into the printing bath. While the Titan 1 uses a stepper motor capable of 5 μm steps, Z-resolution was limited by the resin. The 3DM ABS material has a recommended fabrication range of 50-100 μm due to the photoinitiator/photoblocker selection. Hence, the Z resolution was determined by slicing the model at 50 μm into 331 layers in Creation Workshop. Fabrication of the base layer was for 30 s to allow for secure adhesion to the build platform, layer 2 was half of this at 15 s in order to allow for increased bonding of the rest of the build to the base. Subsequent layers of the design (layers 3-305) were exposed for 2 s, forming the crystal mount "pins". A tapered point was fabricated (layers 306-318) using a lower exposure of 1.5 s in order to prevent overexposure; typically overexposure would result in larger structures than the intended design. Pillars (layers 319-330) forming the loops were exposed for 3 s and 2 s for the top. Total fabrication time was 1 h and 15 min to fabricate 49 loops. All X-ray loops were rinsed in isopropyl alcohol following fabrication to remove any residual, nonpolymerized resin and left to dry at room temperature.

elements.content: The physical structure of the resulting loop “legs” were a layered polymerization of 22 layers of height 41.1 ± 1.2 μm, n = 5; the reduction in height from the intended 50 μm is due to the reduced exposure time required to fabricate the loops. Increased exposure times resulted in the pillars joining together and deforming the loop. The width of the inside of the loop was typically 136 ± 16 μm at the top, 168 ± 21 μm at the bottom, and the height was 411 ± 16 μm, as shown in . The variation in the width in particular is due to back exposure (light penetration through to the previous layer). Due to light intensity drop off (vignetting), fabrication of the loops was not uniform across the whole print; despite this, out of the 49 loops, all were successfully fabricated with usable loop structures. This effect could be corrected in the slicing software, in a similar manner to vignetting correction in photography software such as Photoshop. 3DM-ABS printing resin contains a number of propriety components, as indicated by the manufacturer, such as an acrylic monomer, acrylic oligomer, photoinitiator, acrylic acid ester, and other un-named components. It was found by contact angle analysis that the 3DM-ABS possesses a hydrophilic nature, as indicated by contact angle measurements with deionized water; 51.15° ± 1.54° N = 3 (see Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The photopolymerized loops were prepared at a resin cost of US$0.09 per batch (.stl model volume of 570 mm3, resin cost US$150/L, and excluding the initial cost of the 3D printer, operator, and running costs). The cost of about 0.2 ¢ US per 3D printed mounted loop compares very favorably with commercially available pin-mounted loops including MiTeGen polyimide micromounts and Hampton Research nylon loops (US$5.20 and US$2.66 per mounted loop, respectively).

Increased exposure times resulted in the pillars joining together and deforming the loop. The width of the inside of the loop was typically 136 ± 16 μm at the top, 168 ± 21 μm at the bottom, and the height was 411 ± 16 μm, as shown in . The variation in the width in particular is due to back exposure (light penetration through to the previous layer). Due to light intensity drop off (vignetting), fabrication of the loops was not uniform across the whole print; despite this, out of the 49 loops, all were successfully fabricated with usable loop structures. This effect could be corrected in the slicing software, in a similar manner to vignetting correction in photography software such as Photoshop. 3DM-ABS printing resin contains a number of propriety components, as indicated by the manufacturer, such as an acrylic monomer, acrylic oligomer, photoinitiator, acrylic acid ester, and other un-named components. It was found by contact angle analysis that the 3DM-ABS possesses a hydrophilic nature, as indicated by contact angle measurements with deionized water; 51.15° ± 1.54° N = 3 (see Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The photopolymerized loops were prepared at a resin cost of US$0.09 per batch (.stl model volume of 570 mm3, resin cost US$150/L, and excluding the initial cost of the 3D printer, operator, and running costs). The cost of about 0.2 ¢ US per 3D printed mounted loop compares very favorably with commercially available pin-mounted loops including MiTeGen polyimide micromounts and Hampton Research nylon loops (US$5.20 and US$2.66 per mounted loop, respectively).

elements.content: Microscope image of a 3D printed loop. The width of the inside of the loop was typically 136 ± 16 μm at the top, 168 ± 21 μm at the bottom, and the height was 411 ± 16 μm. Scale bar is 100 μm.
elements.clean_text: 2  Microscope image of a 3D printed loop. The width of the inside of the loop was typically 136 ± 16 μm at the top, 168 ± 21 μm at the bottom, and the height was 411 ± 16 μm. Scale bar is 100 μm.

elements.content: The small molecule and protein X-ray crystallographic data sets were recorded at 100 K on a Bruker AXS D8 Quest with an Incoatec IμS Cu microsource and a Bruker ASX Photon-100 CMOS area detector. Initial scans were undertaken to determine the background scattering of the photopolymerized polymer loops relative to commercially available products. To simulate an authentic data collection, the center of each crystal mounting system was positioned within the X-ray beam, and diffraction data was collected for a 360° scan for 60 s. shows the background scattering for our 3D printed loop, a MiTeGen microfabricated polyimide micromount and the Hampton Research nylon loop. The 3D printed loop showed significantly higher scattering, in large part due to the design and production limitations resulting in significantly more polymer material present within the X-ray beam than the two commercial loops investigated. As will be shown, the higher background scattering did not preclude its use for crystal structure determination.
elements.clean_text:
Diffraction Experiments

The small molecule and protein X-ray crystallographic data sets were recorded at 100 K on a Bruker AXS D8 Quest with an Incoatec IμS Cu microsource and a Bruker ASX Photon-100 CMOS area detector. Initial scans were undertaken to determine the background scattering of the photopolymerized polymer loops relative to commercially available products. To simulate an authentic data collection, the center of each crystal mounting system was positioned within the X-ray beam, and diffraction data was collected for a 360° scan for 60 s.  shows the background scattering for our 3D printed loop, a MiTeGen microfabricated polyimide micromount and the Hampton Research nylon loop. The 3D printed loop showed significantly higher scattering, in large part due to the design and production limitations resulting in significantly more polymer material present within the X-ray beam than the two commercial loops investigated. As will be shown, the higher background scattering did not preclude its use for crystal structure determination.

elements.content: Observed X-ray scattering from (a) 3D printed loop (black); (b) MiTeGen polyimide micromount (pale gray); (c) Hampton Research nylon loop (dotted line gray). Scale bar is 200 μm.
elements.clean_text: 3  Observed X-ray scattering from (a) 3D printed loop (black); (b) MiTeGen polyimide micromount (pale gray); (c) Hampton Research nylon loop (dotted line gray). Scale bar is 200 μm.

elements.content: The suitability of the 3D printed crystal mounts for recording data collections was initially examined with crystals of sodium potassium tartrate (Rochelle salt) mounted to the loop with the use of immersion oil. The crystals could be readily manipulated under a microscope following normal procedures and, with adequate care, the loops could be reused multiple times. However, the loops were found to be more brittle than the commercially available loops, and breakages did occur. The loop was most likely to fail at the junction of the loop to the main pin, as would be expected for a material flexing under the load of pushing and scooping crystals on the surface of a glass microscope slide. Once the crystal had been successfully selected, the sample was placed into the cryostream and the crystal centered in the X-ray beam. Thermal contraction was not observed to be significant upon introduction of the loop into the 100 K stream of nitrogen. The centering of the crystals within the X-ray beam was more challenging due to the relative thickness of the polymer loop and the opacity of the polymer. Data collected with the loops was of high quality and facilitated the solution and refinement of the Rochelle salt test crystals. The data and refinement statistics were close to identical for an individual crystal tested on both nylon and 3D printed loops (data available on the Cambridge Crystallographic Database CCDC numbers 1525822 and 1525823, respectively).
elements.clean_text: The suitability of the 3D printed crystal mounts for recording data collections was initially examined with crystals of sodium potassium tartrate (Rochelle salt) mounted to the loop with the use of immersion oil. The crystals could be readily manipulated under a microscope following normal procedures and, with adequate care, the loops could be reused multiple times. However, the loops were found to be more brittle than the commercially available loops, and breakages did occur. The loop was most likely to fail at the junction of the loop to the main pin, as would be expected for a material flexing under the load of pushing and scooping crystals on the surface of a glass microscope slide. Once the crystal had been successfully selected, the sample was placed into the cryostream and the crystal centered in the X-ray beam. Thermal contraction was not observed to be significant upon introduction of the loop into the 100 K stream of nitrogen. The centering of the crystals within the X-ray beam was more challenging due to the relative thickness of the polymer loop and the opacity of the polymer. Data collected with the loops was of high quality and facilitated the solution and refinement of the Rochelle salt test crystals. The data and refinement statistics were close to identical for an individual crystal tested on both nylon and 3D printed loops (data available on the Cambridge Crystallographic Database CCDC numbers 1525822 and 1525823, respectively).

elements.content: Protein crystals were also examined and were found to be suitable for manipulation and data collection with the 3D printed loops. Lysozyme crystals were grown by a literature method using a 5% sodium chloride solution as a precipitating agent for a 30 mg·mL–1 solution of the protein in a 0.1 M acetate buffer at pH 4.5. The crystals were cryoprotected with a 30% glycerol solution of the crystallizing buffer, and the crystals were rapidly cooled by their introduction into the cold nitrogen stream. An interesting property of the contact angle of the 3D printed loop material was observed for mounting under aqueous conditions as the loops were rapidly wetted by the buffer mixture. This property simplified the mounting of the protein crystal within a protective environment of buffer, which assisted in cryoprotection and cryo-condition crystal mounting. The data was collected by standard methods to 1.8 Å, and the refined structure has been uploaded to the protein database (PDB ID: 5TK0).
elements.clean_text: Protein crystals were also examined and were found to be suitable for manipulation and data collection with the 3D printed loops. Lysozyme crystals were grown by a literature method using a 5% sodium chloride solution as a precipitating agent for a 30 mg⋅mL-1 solution of the protein in a 0.1 M acetate buffer at pH 4.5. The crystals were cryoprotected with a 30% glycerol solution of the crystallizing buffer, and the crystals were rapidly cooled by their introduction into the cold nitrogen stream. An interesting property of the contact angle of the 3D printed loop material was observed for mounting under aqueous conditions as the loops were rapidly wetted by the buffer mixture. This property simplified the mounting of the protein crystal within a protective environment of buffer, which assisted in cryoprotection and cryo-condition crystal mounting. The data was collected by standard methods to 1.8 Å, and the refined structure has been uploaded to the protein database (PDB ID: 5TK0).

elements.content: 3D printed polymer crystal loops have been prepared and examined for their use for small molecule and protein crystallography. The loops were rapidly manufactured, provide mounting structures not currently available, and are prepared at a favorable cost (49 pins from US$0.09 of resin) compared to commercially available crystal mounting systems. The potential to develop new and custom crystal mounting designs, and anticipated advances in the resolution and range of materials for printing will ensure continued interest in the application of microfabrication techniques to experimental crystallography.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

3D printed polymer crystal loops have been prepared and examined for their use for small molecule and protein crystallography. The loops were rapidly manufactured, provide mounting structures not currently available, and are prepared at a favorable cost (49 pins from US$0.09 of resin) compared to commercially available crystal mounting systems. The potential to develop new and custom crystal mounting designs, and anticipated advances in the resolution and range of materials for printing will ensure continued interest in the application of microfabrication techniques to experimental crystallography.

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.analchem.7b00443.

The .stl file used for fabrication of the loops (ZIP).

The same crystal was used for the two following datasets. The first dataset was obtained with use of a nylon loop purchased from Hampton Research. The second dataset was recorded on a loop microfabricated by 3D printing (CIF).

metadata.title:
3D Printed Micrometer-Scale Polymer Mounts for Single
Crystal Analysis
